course.description: Efficient algorithms for multiagent planning, and approaches to learning near-optimal decisions using possibly partially observable Markov decision processes; stochastic and repeated games; and reinforcement learning.
course.name: Reinforcement Learning and Decision Making

reviews.body:
TLDR; This class is very cool. Project 3 is very hard. If you're interested in the material, you should for sure take it.

This is a really cool course. The lectures are very similar quality to ML, so if you liked ML and the corny way Prof. Littman and Isbell lecture you will like this. I found the lectures to be fine. They cover the material, but there is a lack of depth that you are expected to extrapolate from the assigned readings. The other thing to note is that the lectures do not really cover material that is necessary for Project 2 and 3. 
Project 1 was really easy after the horror that was the 10-page papers from ML. If you want to do well read the paper literally everything you need is in that paper.
Project 2 was also pretty easy. I don't recall if they gave the best advice about papers to read and reference for that, but look up DQN, DDPG, PPO, or REINFORCE and you should be able to figure it out. 
Project 3 was very difficult. This project covered MARL in a simplified Overcooked environment. And a big part of why this assignment is hard is because the environment is implemented in python and slow. Start this one as soon as it drops. Clear your calendar for the three weeks the assignment is available. I did not solve all of the layouts, but the penalty for not doing so is "small" (they don't specify what it is exactly).
The HW is all very easy as well. I would recommend getting them out of the way quickly so that you can spend all your energy on the papers.
The Final exam for this class is pretty annoying. There was no provided study guide and no clear communication of what would be on it. But don't worry because as long as you're ahead of the average you should be in good shape. Honestly, feels kinda disingenuous to have a final exam that is multi-choice/ multi-answer for a class that almost entirely focuses on analysis rather than definitions and rote memorization, but I also understand that grading a free response exam would take a lot of time. I got right around 50% and still got an A, so unless you really screwed up your projects or missed a homework I wouldn't sweat it too much.

I'm giving this course a 5 on quality because it was awesome, but recognize this is a graduate level course where most of the learning is done outside of lecture. TAs as always are going to give really vague and unhelpful answers to questions that get to the heart of assignments. I'm giving a 4 on difficulty because I'd say that is the average difficulty level, but Project 3 is seriously no joke and has been the hardest assignment I've worked on at OMS so far.

The lectures for this course were some of the better ones I've seen in OMSCS, of course there is always room for improvement and to teach more state of the art material, but overall was still extremely solid. The assignments were also pretty useful for the most part, especially the projects. I like classes like these where it requires a good deal of time and work BUT the assignments are designed in such a way where you actually learn a TON. Granted, a lot of the learning was done on the projects from my own research, but I also feel like they graded much fairer than other courses (CV and ML4T) and the assignments were not nearly as tedious as other classes (CV). The information learned in doing the assignments and projects was great in my opinion, especially if you have an interest in RL. I wish that continuous action spaces were covered more, along with a more formalized learning of multi-agent RL and how to use RL libraries (since everything was implemented from scratch except NN neurons and backprop). The projects, especially projects 2 and 3, require an insane amount of time so plan accordingly to start VERY early. I got a 100% on the third project but turned it in late and got a late penalty since I didn't allocate my time correctly. I highly recommend this class as it is probably the best one of the 8 courses I have taken.

I had taken AI and DL prior to RL, and I would rank the difficulty of the classes such that RL > AI > DL. I'm very glad that I took RL LAST because this was the class where I underestimated how much effort it would take to absorb the material, let alone just be able to do the assignments! RL is very conceptual and math-heavy, so if you do not understand how and why the math works then you're in for a world of hurt.

Student performance is judged based on 30% Homework (Gradescope submission work), 45% Projects (code to GitHub and research-style paper submissions), and 25% Final Exam (one closed-book exam proctored by HonorLock for 120 min). 

Homework - Other people in OMSCentral have already remarked on the Homework assignments, so I have nothing new to contribute here. Seems unchanged from previous years for Spring 2024. 

Project #1 - I highly recommend to put most of your effort on writing a high-quality research-like report for each project and not being fixated on mimicking the exact results of a research paper and/or getting the "best possible" results for each experiment. I learned this from Project 1 where even though I was able to get results very similar to Sutton's paper of TD Lambda, I still got a 10 point deduction for "not having sufficiently in-depth analysis" in my 5 page paper. To be fair, I agreed with this comment from the grader - I did not know how to best analyze the "whys" of what I was seeing and was not explaining it in a sufficient depth. I am pretty sure the deduction would have been far less if I had been unable to mimic the results of Sutton's paper but was able to explain the theoretical "whys" of why failures happened in my experiments. 

Project #2 - This time around, I quickly coded up a solution that I thought worked sufficiently to address the Lunar Lander AI problem and spent over 1 week writing a report that elaborated much more on the "why" analysis of my experiments. There were pros and cons to this approach, but I wouldn't realize it until Project 3. The pros was that I got zero deductions on Project 2 (full score), which meant my report was solid), and I knew then exactly how yo format any future reports that I would ever need to turn in for RL. The con was
that my agent for Project 2 was not the most efficient, and this would later affect me in Project 3.

Project #3 - This was only the 2nd time that the course had students work on a multi-agent problem that was the Overcooked AI problem, and I could tell they were still observing where they should fix any kinks if they were to have Project 3 remain the same for future semesters. This project made me sick...literally! I spent over 3 weeks spending all my free time reading more than 30 research papers and attempting so many different experiments in order to get some results for a writeup. I lost sleep, had constant headaches, etc. I was not looking for perfection of being able to solve all 5 layouts of Overcooked, but I did panic when I realized that I was getting stuck just solving 2 out of the 5 layouts and not making any progress despite my efforts. 
The teaching staff recommended that as a baseline people try using their single-agent approach from Project 2 to solve Project 3 and see how far they get before attempting any other new multi-agent approaches. This is where my con from Project 2 affected me - since I didn't spend countless hours making the most efficient agent, the agent from Project 2 was only able to solve 2 layouts in Project 3. I spent the next 3 weeks trying new algorithms (and failing), and then resorting back to trying to salvage my agent from Project 2 to solve at least one more layout so that it wouldn't have such a pathetic performance. I ended up being able to only solve 3 out of 5 layouts with my final implementation, but I wrote what I thought was a high quality paper explaining the whys of my successes and failures. Ultimately, I got very small deductions for not being able to solve the remaining 2 layouts and got a higher score than I did in Project 1. The class everage and median for Project 3 was low (in the 70s), and I think this is due to 2 potential reasons. Either people spent all their time doing experiments but didn't put the same amount of focus into their reports, OR people procrastinated and thought they could spend just a few days before the deadline to get everything done (code and report) and quickly realized that Project 3 is 10x harder than both Project 1 and 2 combined. I personally think that if I had spent more time in Project 2 making the most optimal agent possible, then I would have better experimental success in Project 3 because enhancing a very efficient single-agent approach to work for the multi-agent environment would have shaved off a lot of experimentation time for me. 

Final Exam: I needed the high scores from Projects and Homework to save me. I failed this exam so terribly that if you were to look at my performance in relation to the rest of the class for just the exam, it looked like I did not learn a darn thing all semester! I studied and prepared for 7 days prior to the exam, and still "failed". My advice is to not over-prepare by studying the lecture videos - instead, read the relevant chapters from the class textbook and then just take the test. I spent too much time going over lecture videos and not enough time reading the high-level perspectives from the textbook. Also, blind guessing results in points deduction because the final exam is multiple choice with multiple answers for some questions. If you choose 1 wrong choice and 1 right choice for a multiple-answer question, then you get 0 points on that question!

Lecture videos - So awful...this is the first class where I felt like vomiting everytime I started a video to hear the non-stop bantering and joking of the 2 professors who star in the lecture videos. The joking got in the way of me learning anything at all, and they would purposely spend hours deriving something trivial and then wiping the math away to say they deliberately made errors to prove a point. It got to the point where I stopped watching the weekly allotment of videos for 1 month because I couldn't sit through all the unhelpful chatter of the videos. My feedback to the teaching staff was to please just do away with the current lecture videos because they were the worst part of the course (even worse than the experience of taking the final exam).

Teaching staff: This class is so darn RESPONSIVE! This is the first class where the TAs explained their background and hobbies on a Ed post at the beginning of the semester, and it was so nice to know these people were "real people" and not just names on a virtual board that answered questions or graded assignments. Some of the TAs had IMPRESSIVE backgrounds, and I found myself wondering "wow, how high is the caliber of expectations to be able yo qualify as a TA for RL?!". Also, the TAs are hovering around Ed Discussion around the clock, and responses to student questions are posted within a few hours. That is such a crazy difference compared to AI where questions from students could go unanswered for up to 7 days! The TA in charge of Project 3 also spent a lot of time asking for feedback about how to improve Project 3 for the future. The way the TAs helped to run the course is how all classes in OMSCS should run.

Extra Credit: We had an extra credit opportunity this semester, and I did not get it. But if I did, it would have added an extra 10 points to my grade on Project 3. I guess in the end I didn't really need any extra credit because I lost very few points on Project 3 despite dismal experimentation results (solving 3 out of 5 layouts is still just solving 60% of a problem, which is really not something to rave about if I were on a podium). 

Conclusion: I learned SO much, and also worked SO much for Project 3 that I need to find a passion project to showcase everything that I can do now with reinforcement learning! Even though I failed the Final Exam, my performance on Homework and Projects was high enough to still result in an A (with the help of the class curve). I had estimated that this would be a B grade class for me since it took so much effort for me to understand the material, and therefore I was pleasantly surprised to see my final grade in the class!

Very difficult, but in the right ways. This class treats you like an adult and puts you in charge of managing your time and research to get to the finish line. Probably the first class in OMSA that fostered a collegial relationship with TAs (10 classes taken).

Challenging but achievable, and very engaging because of this. Just finishing the class won't get you an A, unlike many other OMSA courses. The projects are hard and you'll have to do some research of your own to succeed. But it's a process that will help you learn a lot in very practical ways. If RL is at all interesting to you, don't miss this class - just take it alone or pair it with something easy.

One thing that holds this course back is that there is an amount of disconnection between the lectures and everything else.  The lectures follow the mathematical theory behind how the various RL topics work.  Then the projects and weekly homework focus on practical applications.  In between those two ends, you have the readings -- they should bridge the gap, but often fall short.  
The readings consist of the Sutton and Barto book, which I did enjoy, and then research papers.  I recommend buying the hard copy of the book because it is foundational and I found it handy to write in the margins and highlight.  I'll be returning to it during self-study a lot.  The research publications are just okay.  Some are far more recent than others, and while the older papers provide some much needed insight into how the RL paradigm has shifted over the past 10+ years, the last third of the class is definitely in need of renovation.
For example, the third project focuses on multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL).  It's been said before, but it is an absolute giant of a project that tested me in so many different ways.  You would think that multi-agent learning would make up some portion of lectures, right?  Negative.  The last third of the class lectures focus on a smattering of topics, mostly game theory.  While game theory was interesting, the MARL domain is so relative today that it was boggling that it wasn't covered in much detail.  That was pushed to a lot of self-study centered around Project 3:  we were given a laundry list of papers to read, pick an algorithm(s) to implement, and build a MARL solution to a cooking environment.  It didn't help that there was a bug in the environment that I got conflicting responses about what it affected.
Overall, this is a difficult, math-heavy course.  It is in need of modernization.  The lectures are dense, and sometimes confusing, and the interplay between the two lecturers is grating at times.  When you just want things explaining simply, it can get frustrating.  There needs to be a better bridge between theory and practice.  Get ready to spend ungodly amounts of time looking at other resources, like the fantastic David Silver lectures or alternative textbooks.  The TAs are great; they're just working within the framework that they've been given.  I enjoyed the first two projects, and yes the final exam is very hard.  I scored in the 50s and was above the course average so it is universally difficult.

If you were inspired to take reinforcement learning after hearing that it was used to train ChatGPT, avoid this course, because you’ll learn none of it unless you self-study, in which case you might as well not take the module at all. IMO, the short reinforcement learning section in ML4T is more applicable to real-life than the entire 7642 syllabus.

Lectures are absolutely useless except for Final Exam, and maybe HW1:
•	Charles is fine but he only teaches a negligible proportion of the syllabus
•	Michael is incomprehensible?? More than once he switches train of thought mid-sentence, and he jumps from concept to concept without any context or explanation. The bantering style of lecturing exacerbates this
•	Lecturing style aside, the syllabus is so theoretical, it teaches you absolutely nothing about how to implement anything, much less best practices in modern RL. This is a massive wasted opportunity because RL is super interesting (as I found out during self-study)

My recommendation is to read the relevant textbook chapters before watching the lectures, then the lectures might make a bit more sense.
The rest of the weekly readings are mostly useless except for the final exam:
•	Believe it or not, the paper introducing deep RL is not even in the reading list. In fact, I don’t think any deep RL papers are on the reading list
•	Most readings were authored in the 1990s, i.e. were focused on solving simplistic computer games. It’s hard to see any application to real life
•	Project 3 has 12 suggested readings in it, all of which are 2016 or later, covering more recent techniques in RL. Why aren’t these in the weekly readings instead?

TAs are insanely helpful & trying their absolute best. I cannot stress this enough. I feel like they themselves know that the course content is useless, but there’s only so much they can do.

Project 3 will have you implementing a multi-agent model (which they don’t teach). As others have already mentioned, this project is an absolute beast, and combining multiple neural nets in 1 model can be very very tricky in PyTorch. Clear all other deliverables ASAP, and get started the moment it’s released.

Finals-wise, know that for multiple semesters, the average grade has been <50%. You’ll need a super deep understanding & memorization of the attributes and properties of the whole syllabus (which is massive). Most of the questions don’t have answers explicitly stated in the lectures or readings. And cheatsheets aren’t allowed.

Super hard course, haha check out my candid review here!
https://youtu.be/LEwjFYt4XIQ

I took this course over the summer (doing my first week of homework on a cruise ship in the Mediterranean) with full knowledge that it is a tough class, but observing that the grade distribution for the class in the summer (https://lite.gatech.edu/lite_script/dashboards/grade_distribution.html) is generally about the same as for the fall and spring. Sure enough, this semester the distribution came out to be 41% A, 28% B, 1% C, 2% D, 2% F, 25% W.

I rate this class only a 3 because the lectures are poor, dated, and lacking relevance. The lectures contain many mistakes which aren't all annotated. Many results are presented only at a high level so that it is difficult to understand the meaning or how to practically apply the results. The continual banter, including debates about the meanings of things, adds to confusion. The lectures don't contain any material on policy gradient methods even though these are arguably the most important and commonly applied techniques in modern RL. It is also annoying that project 3 is all about policy gradient multi-agent methods for which the lectures provide no support at all. As other people have, I recommend the David Silver lectures on Youtube.

One unexpected downside of taking this class over the summer was that only 160 students were enrolled so that there was no critical mass for good Slack discussions. Consequently, everyone gave up on Slack and questions posted there went unanswered. You get better support from other students by taking the class in the Fall or Spring. Fortunately, I had manually copied the Slack discussions from the spring into a Word doc to preserve these before I'd lose access. Having these available and searchable was useful.

As other people have said, project 3 is a beast and really represents a capstone project even though the grade allocation is the same as for projects 1 and 2.  I finished project 2 and the homeworks early so I'd have 3 weekends on project 3. I also took some days off work, ending up spending about 90 hours on the project. 

I was able to significantly beat the baselines on project 3 using CCPPO (following the ray lib example), increasing the size of the central critic NN (because coordinated value estimation is hard), and with lots of reward shaping to incentivize better and more aggressive defense. Reward-shaping is tricky and easily becomes pathological, so this tip may not be much of a tip since it takes a ton of training experimentation to get this working. 

Watch the video visualizations generated by the provided Jupyter notebook. The best baseline (3) wins nearly all games in which the agent team starts with the ball (the odd episodes), but ties most games in which they do not (the even episodes). So the best strategy for improving on this may be to find a way to add an aggressive defense and try to steal the ball and also score on the even episodes. I did this mostly by adding reward shaping to incentivize more aggressive defense. I found this wasn't enough with PPO alone: I needed an algorithm with more coordination.

For my setup, I used docker on my Windows 11 host system using an RTX3090 GPU and a CPU with 20 cores and 64gb ram. Lots of people had trouble with cloud setups and some people were hardly able to complete any training at all, spending most of their time troubleshooting problems and complaining about this on Ed. Following a suggestion someone made in Slack the previous semester. I was able to speed up training significantly by increasing the SGD minibatch size and related parameters, and also the learning rate--so that I could complete a 20 million step training run in around 10 hours (instead of 24). 

The final exam was an exercise in remembering details from the lectures and two papers (KWIK and Sutton 88). I wish I had made a table of methods/techniques/algorithms and their properties and memorizing this as someone suggested in another review. I studied by rewatching all of the lectures and making notes, and studying the posted student answers to study questions, finding other sources for answers when those were weak. This study was enough to get me a score above the upper quartile, but I think I could have done better with added table memorization. The mean score was 46, median 48, and upper quartile 56. 

I ended up with an A, scoring (94,95,97) on the projects, and a 61 on the final.

Reinforcement Learning Review

Reinforcement Learning (RL) is a fascinating class, but I have mixed feelings now that the course has concluded. On the plus side, RL feels like it just might be the next "big thing." The field is a fascinating fusion of classical computer science, statistics, cognitive and neuroscience, and mathematics. Before taking this class and having taken the AI, ML4T, and ML courses, this class felt like what AI should be, or at least, what I expected AI and machine learning to be like; that is, an agent that explores an environment, acquiring feedback and evaluating its progress towards some goal at each step along the way. The agent-centric aspect of RL distinguishes it from other areas of AI and ML, and it is a novel way to think about problems in this space.

On the downside, RL is still very theoretical and has yet to gain traction in industry, as it is not applicable to most commercial use cases. The domains where RL has been successful have been confined mainly to robotics and gaming - although I have heard that large language models like chatGPT used specific RL techniques. RL is an active area of research, and I hope it will find broader appeal as success in new domains and use cases accrue. RL is definitely something to keep your eye on if you are in the Machine Learning or Interactive Intelligence specializations. 

There are three projects (45%), six homeworks (30%), and a final exam (25%) that make up the final grade. There are course lectures, office hours, and a lot of readings. This class is demanding, and the projects require a lot of time. In terms of effort and workload, it is up there with ML and AI, and I easily spent at least 40-60 hours on each project. Preparing for the final was chaotic, and I was "burned out" after P3. The instructors included a series of game theory lectures at the end. Including this material was a little puzzling, at least to me, since none of the homework or assignments involved game theory. However, conceptually there is an overlap between game theory, a la John Nash's "a beautiful mind" equations, and multi-agent RL.

I finished with a final grade of 74%, which was a B. I did below average on the first project and the exam and was at or above the median for the rest. With a little effort, you can get 100s on all HWs - the first one is the hardest, and they get progressively easier and less time-consuming. Understand how to write a good report for the projects - results are less important than showcasing your understanding. For the final, don't overthink it - know the big picture. The average/mean was around 46-48% (I scored a 42%), but it is easy to go down the wrong path in studying since there is so much material. I certainly did.

Lectures and Class Material
The lectures for this class could be better. I did not enjoy them and stopped watching them halfway thru. Some are good, while other modules were just confusing. The focus was mainly on mathematical proofs and lacked a coherent narrative. I don't think the course modules were helpful for the final - they went into too much detail. 

I watched most of the David Silver lectures, which were terrific. The David Silver lectures were coherent and well-paced, each one building on the previous one in a coordinated fashion. The course lectures were less connected and felt arbitrarily stitched together in comparison. Often it was unclear why a proof or equation was being introduced or how it fit into a larger RL context. I often felt "lost in the details." Combing both the Silver lectures and the course lectures is likely the best approach since the Silver lectures provide a layout while using the course lectures to fill in the mathematical details whenever needed - but who has the time to watch so many videos?

Many of the readings were excellent. After you bang your head for a while on an academic paper, it does eventually begin to make sense. I learned quite a bit from the papers and the book. I didn't read everything, and some readings were harder to grasp or seemed to fringe, but the course designers did an excellent job selecting the essential readings in the field. The DQN journal articles and the Sutton paper on TD learning are foundational readings. The Barto and Sutton text was also quite good, at least the early chapters (i.e., 1 thru 7) I had read.

The TAs for the class were talented and generally impressive, particularly the lead instructors. They were very positive and supportive, but your YMMV for the office hours. The TAs preferred facilitating class discussions, letting things flow organically, instead of a more structured guided office hour. Often, I felt they were reluctant to provide solid answers or advice, instead encouraging students to give it their best shot and not be afraid to take some liberties or explore the topic independently. 

Ed discussions were good - lots of class participation but not too much direct involvement from the TAs. Again, they preferred to stay in the background and referee more than actively participate. But they did help direct and clarify topics when necessary. 

Overall a great class and an important and emerging area for those interested in AI. It gets a bit theoretical at times, but the projects were fantastic and provided the necessary hands-on RL experience I was looking for. If you want to prepare for the class, study a bit of dynamic programming and read up on and understand the grid-world MDP problem using value and policy iteration. Learning the basics of PyTorch will come in handy. Understand gradient functions (or read Sutton's Temporal Difference Learning paper). Also, I would learn how to spin up and configure a virtual machine using one of the major cloud providers - that may come in handy for P3 if you don't own a souped-up home machine. Finally, if you have a lot of spare time, watch David Silver's lectures, read his DQN paper, and the first 5 or 6 chapters of Sutton.

Good luck.

I won't spend a lot of time re-iterating stuff that other people already accurately described. TAs good (and very nice, can't praise them enough), assignments very easy, lots of reading, projects generally hard. I'll just provide some more insight into project 3. You could probably submit this project as the capstone project for DL, the one that you have multiple months to do and must complete with a group, and I'm very sure the TAs would OK it; it's that complex. If you aren't intimately familiar with RLLib, I would strongly, strongly recommend spending time earlier in the semester looking through the source code and the examples it contains. Learn how to modify the structure of a neural network or the overall behavior of one of the pre-existing algorithms. That was probably what most of us spent most of our time doing, and it's a real shame, because that cuts into valuable experimentation time. Also, have a fairly modern 6 (really 8) core CPU and 32 GB of RAM MINIMUM if you don't want to be renting a VM from someone. I know everyone always says "start early," which is often not even an option for a lot of people, but really do clear some time for this one, if possible.

That said, I think grading was more lenient on P3 than the other projects. The median ended up higher, while the mean was lower. I did quite well  with, and I can't stress this enough, garbage results. They give a lot of points for demonstrating one's understanding of the principles behind multi-agent RL, and for thoroughly explaining why one's agents performed in the manner they did.

The final was extremely dumb. Assuming they keep the multiple-choice format, my recommendation would would be to simply re-watch the lectures, making note of any time they define something or describe the performance characteristics of some algorithm. (how well it does/what kind of environments it can operate in/what information it needs in order to work). You should be able to beat the curve with that alone. They provided a lot of study questions in Ed, but I wish I spent less time on them, as rote memorization would have almost certainly earned me a better score.

I hope they are able to improve/streamline P3, because it seems like a project with a lot of potential that was simply too difficult and complicated for most people to get working and then have time to conduct detailed experimentation in a timeframe of 3-4 weeks (Again, start early if you can. Neglect your children if you have to!). I think the idea was to give people this powerful RL framework with which would allow them to spend less time implementing and more time experimenting, but I think the opposite ended up happening.

This class is pretty great and feels like a grad class. The homeworks are easy expect HW1 which I found to be pretty stressful and difficult. I will say the TAs were pretty amazing throughout the entire class and were very supportive. A lot of students too were very involved which made for a fun time as a fellow student.

The projects are all good:

Project 1-  Pretty easy to follow pseudo code from the book and other students discuss little tricks they had to do to get the exact results on here as well as in your slack. 

Project 2- Fun project, I used a DQN. Feels sort of out of left field to be learning some DL, but once you get past that hump its not too hard. Still a lot of work and time to train and tune, but its pretty fun to do and overall enjoyable.

Project 3- New project as of the last year or two. Really really really hard. I was not able to beat the baselines we had to train against despite trying all sorts of strategies. I trained locally, and you need at least 18gbs of memory to train your model. Spent lots of time and effort on this and felt bad to not get good results. Most of my time was spent scouring github libraries for MARL to try and understand how to implement a decent agent and make it work in RLLIB.

All of these projects require you to start the minute they open otherwise your chances of finishing them and getting a good grade is very slim. 

Exam-
The exam was total BS. Some of the questions were about an algorithm that we never talked about. The review questions did not really prepare you. The TAs were suppose to post answers but they never did. While I liked the idea of us learning off each other, please also post the answers!

I also tried to take it at my parents house while on vacation so I bombed it as I rushed through it. Oh well, my exam grade doesn't reflect how much I learned. I had pretty much aced every single homework and project and still did so incredibly poor on the final.

Lectures-
I didn't mind the jokey tone that smoov and curly took in this one, but a few of the topics in the middle where just like straight math proofs with no real explanation of how they connect to the topics. It was fine, and I would never say the lectures are bad, but I wouldn't say they blew me away either. As others have mentioned David Silver's lectures are much better and I would recommend watching those. Like a good grad class, you will need to do a lot of learning outside of the provided materials. In this class it's cool to read papers that are cutting edge and interesting, and be able to understand them.

Overall-
TAs were really good. TJ and Jake in particular (as well as others!)  who ran our office hours were always very supportive. It's a fun, challenging class that despite the final I'd take again.

This is probably the most difficult course I've taken in my entire academic career. Thankfully, the difficulty isn't artificial and doesn't come from needless busywork, but rather from the intensity of the material itself.

The course is broken down into six homeworks, three projects, and one exam. The six homeworks are auto-graded in Gradescope and cover the material from the lectures/readings and help give a good foundation for thinking about the projects. The projects are interesting in that you are *not* graded on your implementation at all, but rather on your interpretation of your results, and the exam is a multiple choice exam that covers all of the material in the course.

The homeworks don't have anything of note in them that makes them stand out - they're fun and interesting, but a bit foundational. Once you crack the main idea of the problem, the implementation is generally straightforward.

The projects are real work. You'll end up writing a ton of code and submitting it, but it's basically only checked to make sure it runs and isn't a copy of another implementation. The effort comes from writing the reports and coming up with justifications for how you approached the problem, and (more importantly) showing that you understood the problem. My undergraduate degree was a writing degree, and these projects felt like a real synthesis of all of my skills. I enjoyed the process, though I generally spent a single day writing the report, which I wouldn't recommend unless you have experience writing a 15 page paper in 10 hours. It melted me and affected basically everything else in my life.

One thing to mention about the projects is that the work starts hard and gets mind-blowingly difficult. The third project leans heavily on compute power and understanding the RLlib abstraction, and if you wander off in the woods for any amount of time, you will likely not be able to solve the problem. I was not able to beat the benchmarks, mainly because I had a significant amount of difficulty understanding the RLlib abstraction and figuring out how to write and debug my own code. I spent about 100 hours on the project, but beat the median only by a little bit, mainly because I wasn't able to come up with excellent points because I didn't fully understand what was going on. It was humbling, but (most importantly), it made me thirsty for more.

The final, though, was awful. They give you a study guide with open-ended problems, but don't give you the answers they think are right. Given that the students argue over definitional true/false questions, this makes it really difficult to study and know if you are on the right track. Couple that with the fact that the exam doesn't reflect what was in those study guides, and the average for the final was about a 45 and the highest grade was an 80.

I don't think the exam was difficult enough to warrant this, and the main problem with it was the lack of getting the students prepared. I think they can solve this by offering gigantic question banks they draw from for the exam, and offering guidance on how to approach the problems. 

Outside of the exam, this course was excellent and felt like a real graduate course (instead of undergraduate+, like GIOS and ML4T) as the focus was on interpretation and analysis rather than code.

I would recommend this course, but understand there are points where you're likely going to want to give up and/or cry and/or hallucinate from lack of sleep.

Heavy workload if taking another course, TAs are engaged and not snarky, 2 office hours sessions a week, covers the classics, but also gets into the newer DRL stuff. Lots of papers to read and process, which is fun and feels more like a graduate class than some other courses.

Assignment grading is slow, which seems by design (given there is no shortage of TAs). You just have to have confidence that you're doing the right things.
It is the best class that I took in OMSCS so far. You definitely learn a lot. The topics are eye opening. It is harder than AI, ML and DL imo.

Overall - It is the most insightful and difficult course I've taken so far (KBIA, ML4T, AI4R), which is to be expected from the reviews. Loved project 1 and project 2, reading papers and trying to implement TD(lambda) and DQN was super fun! 

Project 3, I have no idea what I was doing. I feel like it was such a huge step up from P1 and P2, and I was not making any progress in any meaningful way. rllib is a monster of abstraction which is pretty much the crux of the project. I would recommend anyone taking this course in the future, try to implement P2 in rllib after doing it in just PyTorch. Also, you'll need a machine that is good enough the train for P3. I know the TAs did not explicitly say this but if you can't train 1 million timesteps within 1 hour, you need a better/faster machine. This is the ONLY way to know that what you are doing is making an impact on the agent. 

Homework was trivial, given that this is not your python course, you'll be fine. 

The Final was brutal. As stated in various posts, the average was in the 40s. I rewatched the entire lecture videos, read various sections of the book, and did the practice exam twice. After all of that, I still got the average. 

Time spent per week: 20+ 

Conclusion: ML specialization, this is a must. Even if ML is not your specialization, you might as well take it. Everything else will be a walk in the park.

Very interesting and engaging material, but extremely time consuming course. Would not recommend taking another course at the same time if you're a part time student. I found the lectures in the course material hard to follow and keep up with, the David Silver lectures on YouTube cover a good chunk of the same material and I found those much easier to understand.
The final project is very computationally demanding, you should have a decent GPU, a high end CPU, and at least 64GB of RAM available you if want to train on your own system. 
After dedicating over 90% of my free time after my job to this course, I was able to pull off a final grade of B.

It was my 10th course in OMSCS. Some feedback may not contain too many details due to the large class size. Nonetheless, this course is well-managed by TAs. 

1. Homework. HW1-6s are simple and easy to implement. HW5-6 may require additional readings regarding KWIK and game theory. 

2. Projects. They are most time-consuming. I didn't work well in Project 1 but achieved 100 in Project 2 and Project 3. The key is to explain your methods, experiments, and analysis thoroughly. That's the reason why TAs recommend IEEE templates. The main structure of the analysis is describing phenomena -- providing hypotheses -- validating your conclusion theoretically and experimentally. IEEE papers usually separate experiments and results. But I recommend combining them because of the 5-pages limitation. It is also convenient to read and prune. Besides, I strongly recommend following Kaiming He's writing style in the ``Masked Autoencoders`` paper. You can highlight or bold key concepts at the beginning of paragraphs.      

Project 1 focuses on TD-lambda. You need to introduce TD methods, replicate experiments and provide your own analysis. Showing your understanding of each experiment is the crux. But I couldn't realize it until submission. 

Project 2 is about deep reinforcement learning, specifically, the DQN series. Two experiments include the training phase and hyperparameter-tuning. It is easy to talk a lot about hyperparameters, like model architecture, learning rate, discount factor, and epsilon-greedy. However, don't forget to describe your training result and analysis in detail. 

Project 3 introduces multi-agent reinforcement learning and plays a Google research football game. The provided baselines depend on PPO. PPO is such a robust algorithm that you may fail to achieve some improvements. So I suggest using QMIX, MAPPO, or other SOTA methods directly because each trial may take several days (So sorry that I was not able to reply to some questions in Edstem). I trained MAPPO on Google cloud and paid 50 dollars plus 300 free credits. Although it is manageable to use GCP with only the free credits, the high computing requirements (especially CPUs) cause much trouble in coding and debugging. For RLlib-based implementation, I recommend seeing some GitHub extensions, such as epymarl and MARLlib. As for the report, except for win-rate improvements, you need to select or customize parameters to display team coordination. 

3. Exam. Important Relevance: Sutton & Barto's book > David Silver's slides > lecture videos. Although lecture videos don't cover all concepts, you can still achieve an above-average grade by only watching them. 

Overall, I think this course is a real graduate-level course in OMSCS. If you have some questions, don't be afraid to ask TAs on Edstem and watch the office hours.

Background: Non-CS, process engineering
Prior Courses: KBAI (A), ML4T (A) 
 
I wanted to get into ML but couldn't get past the waiting list. So I took this first.

My current standing is: 
Project 1: .5 STD above median
Project 2: (probably) .5-1.0 STD below median
Project 3: not due for 5 weeks
HWs: All 100% 
Final: ???

ML isn't necessary for taking RL. 

ML4T helped in some respects because I already had a general idea of what 'learning' was, what is a Markov Decision Process, how to deal with NumPy, and how to do Q-learning. Q-learning is one of the HW assignments and is a general idea behind DQN which has many use for project II. ML4T was an advantage, but I don't think it's necessary. 

This course requires a LOT of reading. This course for reading is as KBAI is for writing. The lectures are really thick with theory and math as well. You will spend more time reading research papers and textbooks than writing code. If you are a theoretically inclined person, this course will suit your strengths. If not, you will struggle. I haven't had to 'use' or derive any math yet, but you need to follow to understand. 

I enjoy the projects and the homework assignments are fun little challenges. I have yet to start on the final project or take the final exam, but the final project looks like a real challenge.

My advice is to re-read everything after you get about halfway into the course. So much of the readings were illegible to me until after completing project I. Then, what was previously alien, became plain English.  In addition to that, I will watch the David Silver lectures. I would expect to do well on the final with this strategy.

Just watch David Sliver's lectures. 
Ambiguous instructions in projects. No rubrics. Grading depends on TA's mood.

Avoid this course if you have better options. UCL or Edinburgh RL course is much better.

The video quality is really low. You have to learn by yourself. The project sucks. The project prescrption is much less to be detailed. You don't know   the points for each part. The grade you got would be unbelievably low. If you argue, you would be deducted 10 points. Seemed decided on your luck to meet a good TA. Totally ruined my semester and good mood. QUit.

Not much to say here that hasn't been said in previous reviews:
Taking this course in the summer is a behemoth and I do not recommend anyone take this course with another course in the summer (or even in the fall and spring). Not because of most of the course, but because of the final project.

(6) HW's that accout for 30% of the grade and start with a first really difficult HW and get progressively easier as the course goes on. HW 5 and 6 are an absolute joke compared to HW 1. Aim to get 100's on all HW's, which is very doable.

(3) Projects, 45% of the grade (15 each). The best and most rewarding part of the class IMO. 1st project on re-proving TD learning, which is quite easy to do but doubly easy to get a bad grade on since TA's are hit-and-miss on what they take points off for. Highly recommend focusing on theory and analysis of data for the reports and little on the actual implementation. The TA's want to know what you learned from the results and implementation, and why you implemented it; not how you implemented it. Embody that in your report and a better grade will follow. 
The second project is the OpenAI Lunar Lander which is really fun and allows you to use whichever agent and algorithm of your choosing. The perfect project, harder than the first but very rewarding in terms of knowledge and application if done properly. 
The third project is an absolute behemoth. Prepare yourselves for hours to just get acquainted with the project. Start as soon as possible. Read as much literature as possible. Fully understand the provided code and objective before throwing stuff against the wall and seeing what sticks. I highly recommend approaching the problem like a scientific experiment, and write the report as such. Have a hypothesis on why a particular technique will work, explain why you think it will work, then implement it and gather good results. Write the report detailing this hypothesis - theory -(small bit on) implementation - (large chunk on) analysis of results. My report followed this format and, even though the agent did not improve upon baseline, since my report showed clear understanding of the literature and results I still received an A. The average is very low for this project since most people just use an inbuilt algorithm and see if it works without really understanding what it is they are doing or why they are doing it. Highly recommend going the reward-shaping route (not based on my project but on high-performing others).
(1) 25% Exam which is honestly a gotchya. They should really change the exam as this has been a real black eye for the class for as long as reviews have been here. Nothing new, 50% avg grade. Know the material and you should do well enough to beat the average, but nothing will properly prepare you for the exam since it is all gotchya's.

ML really put me through the wringer. I expected RL to be less stressful because the assignments are less open-ended. It was, in much the same way that being punched in the stomach is less stressful than being kicked in the crotch.

The projects are great; I learned a ton and I'm excited to go do more experimentation on my own. In each project, it felt like there was some mysterious thing that I never figured out standing between me and the expected results, hence the stress. Fortunately, this doesn't prevent you from doing well in the class. Scoring is less harsh than ML but perhaps more harsh than most courses; correspondingly, the grading curve is less extreme than ML but still unusually generous (the cutoff for an A during this term seemed to be somewhere a little below 80%).

The TA team was fantastic. I think I got a lot out of both the textbook and the (large list of) assigned papers. The lectures were hit-and-miss - not as great as the ML lectures (but lectures are my least favorite way to learn anyway).

I used about $430 worth of Google Cloud resources for project 3. Currently Google gives you $300 for free if it's your first time using it; I paid the rest out of pocket. I'm not sure this was necessary, but I think it made things easier for me. GPUs aren't important for the project, but having lots of processor cores is.

Advice:

- Don't take it in summer. The class has a ton of reading, and the projects involve experiments that take significant time to run, so spreading things out more would have been really nice. In particular, having only 2 weeks for project 2 sucked.
- On project 3, if you aren't seeing good results quickly, try several different approaches. I think I wasted too much time trying to figure out what was going wrong with one particular approach, when other options would have yielded good results more easily.

Conclusion: This is a course with both significant advantages and disadvantages. Be very careful of taking it during a summer session.

Background: Quant, with a B.S. in Physics and M.S. in Financial Engineering.

Final grade: A

Pros
- Extensive coverage, including some new research in RL field.
- Course is taught in a relatively clear way.
- Final grade is curved generously.
- You actually do not need that much maths.

Cons
- The last project is way too time-consuming and requires A LOT OF computational resources. Better have a nice GPU before start.
- The final exam does not have a lot to do with the lectures. It covers some readings, and details in the homework/projects as well. You can easily spend plenty of time preparing for it and get a low grade (as I did :D)
- The professors talk about too many topics, but do not express some fundamental concepts in a clear way.

Somehow I found this class more straightforward than Machine Learning, despite it being a similar format. I scored 100% on all projects/homeworks, and 61% on the final. I really enjoyed it, especially the projects.

The homeworks are guaranteed points, which you will need for your grade to survive the harder assignments. The first couple of them are the hardest, and the last 2-3 are trivial.

There are people (not me) who got 100% on projects with only 3.5/5 pages. The most important thing is touching on every part of the assignment prompt in some depth. The grading is both harsher than you expect if you don’t do this, and more lenient than you expect if you do.

The final exam is total BS. It’s all gotchas. The highest score was 78%, and the mean (excluding 0’s) was slightly over 50%. You must do well on the homeworks and projects to survive the hit from the final exam. They release a study guide ahead of time, but it does not cover everything. Official statements were that the exam would only cover lectures. This was not true. There were some concepts on the Final that were only covered in the readings.

For Project 2, DO NOT TUNE BY HAND. Use a tuning library like *optuna*. This will save you so much personal time, even if not compute time.

The best way to prepare is to get familiar with Ray and Rllib libraries at least several weeks before the release of Project 3. My weekly workload was 10 hours or even less some weeks, 30 hours in the last week of Project 2, and 50+ hours per week throughout the whole Project 3 window.

This is a great course. The TAs are particularly great; I have never seen such an engaging TA team. (Usually the TAs are not responding to questions in EdStem or Piazza, and I hardly seen a TA in Office Hours. But in this course, the TAs usually respond to your EdStem question on the same day, and you can even see many of them actively explaining things in Office Hours, which really surprised me a lot.)

The Assignments are usually easy, except Assignment 1, which is super hard, in particular if you want to get 100% correct; the key to Assignment 1 is that you have to rethink and simplify your model until it trims down to just a table or list with only a few columns that can represent the infinite games for that particular problem. It is not easy so please start early. The other assignments, particularly the last two, are easy in order to give your more project time (I think).

Project 3 (i.e. final) is super hard. Projects 1 and 2 are OK. Project 1 is about Sutton famous TD-learning paper and represents a fair amount of work. Project 2 is about a game in Google AI Gym and is also fair; I used DQN and got good experiment results, though the project report did not yield my expected score (which I think TA should give more textual review on my report content, but anyways). Unfortunately, Project 3 is a nightmare! (I suggested TAs to open this final Project 3 a few weeks earlier in the next semester.) Project 3 is so diffcult because it asks you to use RLlib (which is an open source tool for deep reinforcement learning) and you have to work on Dec-POMDP, which is perhaps the most difficult topic in reinforcement learning. TAs already simplified the problem, but still it is hard and takes very long to train. The problems that I encountered in Project 3 includes:

- No good environment for problem solving: TA suggested either Docker, native setup, or Colab, but in fact all of them have problems.
    - Docker: It is easy to deploy/setup for running, but I cannot scale it up since Docker network sucks on Mac and Windows. I wanted to setup RLlib cluster so that RLlib can train with my 3 old machines, but since the RLlib node is running inside a Docker container, the RLlib head node cannot talk with the other RLlib nodes via the Docker bridge/host network (which only works on Linux but not on Mac or Windows; a problem haunting in Docker for years). Docker is great but has so many network problems on desktops (perhaps Docker network options are designed for servers), therefore Docker is a limitation to upscaling of training.
    - Native setup: It has so many compat problems with Python / make / C and everything. My recommendation is: don't try it, for the sake of limited project time.
    - Colab: It is good for GPU but not good for CPU, since Google only offers 2 vCPUs. This project needs a GPU and many CPUs (to rollout the samples to environment for "bootstraping", I guess), so even 24 or 48 CPUs will not be too many.
    - Google Cloud Platform GCP or Amazon Cloud AWS: Personally I think this is the best option, since you can create a VM with lots of CPUs and one high-end GPU to run your training efficiently. Nevertheless, this comes with a cost (USD 300 for me), which is equal to 1/3 of the course fee! Note that the TAs already recommend us NOT to spend money on cloud platform to get a good grade, and they also promised that they will only look at my analysis writing on project report instead of my source code performance; nevertheless, I admit I am spiritually weak so I cannot tolerate 50 hours of turn-around time for experiment or hyperparameter tuning. Having said that, if you are a new subscriber to GCP, Google may grant you a USD 300 credit (which perhaps expires in months) which you may use for this project.

- RLlib: It is a defacto standard for deep reinforcement learning, but it is still in active development, so many features are experimental. Limitations are not well documented. You have to keep the rollout size low or the multi-CPU rollout process will consume your expensive GCP 300GB memory very quickly. The framework is flexible but is also complex, so even if experiments are achievable, they need much time to work with. QMIX is achievable but you have to pay attention with state action grouping and python/string/dict issues. In order to make QMIX works, I modified RLlib source codes and patched them into the Docker container image, which requires a long investigation. So please count this task into your project schedule as well.

- 60 hours for each training: I am using a Macbook 2018 Pro with 6-core CPU and it took 60 hours to finish training just one default PPO agent. Please note if you design your own RL agent then it may converge poorly due to incorrect design or bugs, so waiting 60 hours for deciding another retry is just too luxurious for a 4-week project. That was why I switched to GCP, which accelerates the training to 10 hours (at the cost of USD 300), yet I still have to permaturely terminate many trainings or hyperparameter tunings in order to speed things up.

Understanding Dec-POMDP and relevant algorithms are relatively easy, when compared to all these hardware/platform issues. I did QMIX and even modified the algorithm a bit, and I think QMIX is achievable. Many others did PPO with center-critic, since PPO is kind of like RLlib preferred algorithm, though I found it hard to hack around the RLlib framework to sneak in the center-critic. On the other hand, since PyTorch and deep learning is a must for using RLlib in project 3, I would also recommend you to take the Deep Learning course before you take this course.

Exam is hard since it contributes to 25% of final grade (while project 3 only contributes to 15%) and it requires you to remember lots of material. Frankly I like Prof. Isbell and Littman, and their worked exmaples in the video lectures are really good for understanding, but the videos contain lots of irrelevant inside jokes, which is not good for memorization. I also could not find any presentation slide pack. So I recommend you to re-watch all videos (incl. all Office Hours, which explains Sutton 88 and KWIK) and write down all equations in clear text (in Microsoft Words) with standardized symbols, so that you can remember all equations or even cross reference them. I also recommend you to download all videos (either via UdaCity or via a browswer plugin) so that you can rewatch them at 2x speed on any device without network latency. Also the TAs are so kind to post a list of review questions on EdStem; answering all of them should help you get a pass (though not necessarily a high score). That being said, I did not score well in exam; I score 60, while the top score was ~80 and the average was ~45.... Now you see how difficult it is. (The exam choices are ambiguous and your score can easily be deducted by a few missing ticks).

Prof Littman is good; he said he is not officially one of the course instructor, yet he allocated chat time for us on Office Hours. He is also very responsive to our review questions when we are preparing the exam. Prof Isbell is diffcult to be commented, since I never saw him anywhere on EdStem or Office Hours, but he is busy working as the Dean of Computing College, and he did arrange Prof Littman to chat with us. On the other hand, I have to appreciate the TAs again, since they are really the best TAs that I have ever seen in my OMSCS journey, where I already have taken 8 courses.

Final verdict: It is a contemporary course, despite that Bellman equation was invented 60 years ago. Before I took this course I thought I will be taught only the classic theories, like dynamic programming or so. It is until the last project that I know deep reinforcement learning can be the hottest topic, incl. AlphaGo and others. The amount of things that you can play with Deep RL is tremendous. (Though Prof Littman mentioned that many students turned out to use algorithms other than RL to solve specific problems.) Overall, this is a good course. Thank you TAs!!

WOW! This is an amazing class - both challenging and exciting at the same time.

This was my 9th course in OMSA. I have a non-cs background and I took this class because I really enjoyed CDA. 

I think the OMSA C-track experience would have been incomplete without taking this course. This course has amazing content and really awesome projects. The only pre-requisite is having enough time.

Assignments: They are really easy if you understand the concepts. No assignment is more than 20lines of code. Try to finish them as soon as you can so that you can spend more time on the project. Scoring full marks is really easy so make sure you do it.

Project: Project 1 and 2 are way easier than project 3. Hence, it is important to do well in the first two of them. The trick is to 'think and communicate'. I would implement the required algorithm a week before it is due and spend the week thinking about the results I got, conduct additional experiments and write all the work in an orderly manner. For Project 3, my only advice is to start early. The detailed reviews of the past students were a huge help. I got a near perfect score 299/300 on the projects.

Exam: I found Exams to be the most difficult part because there is so much content to cover. Also, the multiple answers add to the difficulty. Only way to prepare is to consistently spend 1-2hrs a week (which I did not do) and then spend the last three days revising everything. I re-watched Prof David Silvers first five videos before the exams. 

I really enjoyed this course. TAs are awesome and Prof Littman is very active on Ed. We also had a special OH by Prof Littman (Yeah we were lucky ducks :))

Overall: This was a very fun but demanding class. Fortunately, grades are heavily curved so ~80 probably gets you an A. I had an 88 final grade and got an A. Lectures were OK. I'm not a fan of Professor Isbell and Littman going back and forth making bad jokes, surprisingly, because I was fine with CV lectures' bad dad jokes. Make sure to watch David Silver's RL lectures, they really helped me understand the concepts.

- HWs: The HWs start off being "hard" and then get "easier". What I mean by that is that RL is a whole new way of thinking and takes some time to adjust. The first HW isn't actually hard but takes everyone the longest because they're just not used to it. The HWs are the best way to boost your overall grade. It is entirely on gradescope and the TAs are really helpful for answering questions both on Ed and during office hours. So make sure to get 100s on these.

- Projects: The projects are the hardest part of this class. During the week before the projects are due, I would often spend ~30 hours working on the projects. This is because they are both hard and writing the paper is a lot of work. 

- Project 1 is about fully understanding temporal difference learning paper by Sutton and replicating the graphs. This project isn't particularly fun since you have to replicate a paper, but I appreciated this assignment later in the course, because TD learning is fundamental in a lot of RL algorithms. 

- Project 2 is a really fun project, I enjoyed it a lot. You are basically trying to beat a game using RL algorithms. Most people use the DQN algorithm as it is really popular. There is a good amount of hyperparameter tuning though, so try to make each run as fast as you can to do additional tuning. Heres a hint, gamma will be your most important hyperparameter.

- Project 3 is a new project. The old project, I believe is replicating another paper on multi-agent RL. The new project involves trying lots of different multi-agent RL algos and other aspects specific to multi-agent. Since this was the first semester they did this project, there were a lot of bumps that hopefully they improve on in the future. If I had to redo the project, I would probably get started on the project earlier and get as much computing resources I can (without spending too much money). I wish they gave us another week or two to do this project, because it felt a bit rushed with only 3 weeks. Overall, this was a fun project but I was extremely stressed doing this project. Luckily, the grading on this project was fairly lenient.

- Some advice for writing the papers:
a. Order of importance: Analysis/Results -> Methods/Solution Setup -> everything else. The ultimate goal of the paper is to demonstrate to the TAs you understand what you were doing and why you were doing it, and that primarily shines through in the analysis/results and methods section. 
b. Use the IEEE latex format they recommend. It is more space efficient and make your life easier to fit the 5 page constraint.
c. Spend some time talking about pitfalls and obstacles but not too much as it can bog things down.

- Exam: The exam was my least favorite part of the class. It makes up 25% of the grade, but a lot of the questions are vague/ambiguous and based on small facts the professors might have mentioned in passing. I rewatched the lectures at 2x speed right before the exams and got a 62/100. I wish they would either lower the grade percentage or make the exam test more on general principles in RL instead of obscure facts.

My Background: This was my first semester in OMSCS and I took RL and RAIT. My prior ML/DL experience was useful for RL, especially the projects.

Here's my review of the course content:

1. The video lectures are great overall in terms of breadth but cover some outdated or seemingly not very useful topics (like averagers in module 8, Bayesian RL in module 9). Nevertheless, the breadth of video lectures is simply amazing - covering a wide range of topics (like RL algorithmic analysis, reward shaping, exploration-exploitation tradeoff in bandits and MDPs, POMDPs, Options, Game Theory, multi-agent coordination-communication-coaching) with great clarity. The instructors also do not shy away from presenting the necessary math and proofs, which is great for a Masters class. But, policy gradient methods (which are driving current RL research) are not covered in the videos. Also, basic RL concepts (like Policy Iteration, Value Iteration, Prediction vs Control, On vs Off Policy Learning, Online vs Offline algorithms, Planning vs Learning, etc.) are either not emphasised much or not explained properly in the videos. For this, I would advise what I did before the semester started: watch at least the first seven RL lectures by David Silver on Youtube and take notes since these will prove very useful for the projects and final exam. Most of the material in David Silver's lectures is directly from Sutton & Barto textbook, and thus, it also helps cover some of the assigned readings from the textbook.

2. Homeworks: Fairly easy to get 100% except for HW1. OH discussions are useful in solving HWs. 

3. Project 1 (Sutton 1988 replication): Fairly straightforward. To replicate paper's graphs closely, use 5 sequences in a set instead of the 10 mentioned in the paper - this trick worked for most students. My report consisted of introduction, env description, TD-lambda desc, experiments (with pseudo-code), and analysis. For writing analysis, David silver lecture is very useful. For all reports, I would suggest to use Latex and have 2+ pages for analysis since the bulk of the grade lies in showing your understanding. Remember to mention the pitfalls encountered in the project (make up some pitfall if you did not encounter any for such a simple project) or else you will be penalised some points irrespective of how good your analysis is - this is what happened to me - I ended up with 94/100. 

4. Project 2 (Lunar Lander): Most students use DQN. DQN implementation is not very difficult if you know PyTorch. My report consisted of introduction, env description, desc of Q-Learning, Deep Q-learning (NN architecture, experience replay, target network, exploration-exploitation tradeoff), DQN pseudo-code, experiments, analysis, pitfalls and future work. Hyperparameters experimented with were hidden layer size, num of hidden layers, gamma, alpha, epsilon_start, epsilon_final, epsilon_decay. I also performed ablations by removing experience replay and target network. I got 100/100 since I had done extensive experimentation and also analysed all the hyperparams' results. Choose gamma wisely (very close to 1) since it can make or break training. 

5. Project 3 (Football): This was the first semester for this new project. It is a great research project since the students need to figure out everything from the algorithm to the evaluation metrics. It requires reading quite a few of papers. Students tried methods like QMIX, MADDPG, COMA, centralized critic PPO, reward shaping, curriculum learning, feature engg, etc. I tried QMIX and spent a lot of time getting it to train successfully but it didn't. Most successful methods seemed to be centralized critic policy-gradient methods (like centralised critic PPO) and I would suggest trying these straightaway instead of wasting time on QMIX. My report consisted of introduction, football env desc, Dec-POMDP desc, QMIX and pseudo-code, policy-gradients' brief desc (since baselines were trained using PPO), experiments, analysis, pitfalls and future work. I was able to show using metrics that QMIX improves coordination although not the win rates. Eventually, because of clear explanation, well articulated experiments, nicely explained motivation and challenges, and choice of effective metrics for analysis, I managed to score 93/100 - This is consistent with what the TAs stated about the project - You can write a solid paper even if you cannot beat the bselines' win rates. Two major downsides of this project are machine setup (definitely use docker if possible since it simplifies a lot of things - I setup the native environment (to have access to more RAM compared to docker setup) by manually installing all required packages only to find python version incompatible with the provided checkpoints and ultimately had to also setup docker) and long training times (takes at least a day on the very best of machines to perform a single run). 

6. Final Exam: Make great notes while watching the videos (note each piece of detail carefully) and study it thoroughly before the exam to score high on the exam. I did not find any paper / textbook readings useful for the exam though I would suggest glancing over two of them (Sutton 1988 - Project 1 and KWIK - HW5). Also, David Silver slides / lecture notes are a great refresher for the early part of the course and prove helpful for scoring well in the exam. By following this process, I ended up with 88/100. 

Final Grade: 95/100.

Finally, TAs are amazing and conduct the course smoothly although a few appearances by the instructor in the OHs would be definitely appreciated.
It's quite difficult. Especially the theoretical part of the RL's (convergence, etc) are well covered. Project 3 requires a decent amount of RAM and patience because the training takes a while.

Okay class. I am not a fan of the lectures but the TA's do a great job of helping people out when they have questions. The homework assignments are fairly straightforward and if you follow the classes pace you're pretty much able to do them when they come out. 

There are three big projects in the class and each one is a monolith requiring a significant amount of time to pick away at. This is the area where I feel the class is both the most challenging but also immensely satisfying once concluded. 

The only big complaint I have is that for some reason they don't release all the assignments and projects at the beginning of the semester. Also the grading feels really inconsistent sometimes, for two of the projects I felt that I answered all of the prompts, but I was still graded poorly for things unrelated to those.

For anyone planning on taking this, here's what I would advise:

- Watch the class lectures and supplement them with the popular YouTube series by DeepMind. The professors do a good job covering the topics but I always felt like there were always gaps when I was doing the assignments. The reading also patches this so don't skip.

- Start the projects as early as you possibly can, projects 2 & 3 in particular are incredibly challenging if you haven't done any sort of reinforcement learning or deep learning before. A lot of your project time is more setting up and writing the paper than experimenting, so you want to get through things early.

- If you're stuck on HW or a project, don't be afraid to ask the TA's for help and watch the office hours. The office hours are incredibly useful.

This class was really tough in Summer semester. I would recommend taking it during Fall or Spring so you have more time to digest the many interesting papers and have time to properly tackle the assignments.

Projects were quite difficult and would have preferred more focus on developing agents like the Lunar Lander project rather than replicating papers twice.

The homeworks can be easy or hard depending on the week.

The amount of reading + lectures is intense, but it's possible to get by primarily with just video lectures. There were tons of topics covered from basic methods to game theory, would have liked to see simple non-academic applications covered.

This is the most philosophically interesting class in the program so far for me (4 classes in) and has a strong academic and research focus. This is a great class if you are interested in theoretical CS, theoretical AI, and social science (i.e. economics, cognitive science). To succeed, learn how to write a good research paper, read the assigned readings, and don't skip the lectures when things get hectic as the final exam will cover that material.

Reinforcement Learning is a bit of a weird course in that it has a strong academic flair to the class. Personally, I agree with the way the class is taught. Rather than focusing on the applications of RL, the class requires you to truly understand the thoughts of the researchers that published cutting edge work in the field. This is much more valuable for understanding the fundamental difficulties of working in RL than hacking together some code for something that works. 

The core of the class is in the 3 major projects, each covering an important algorithm in RL. You're required to write everything in 5 pages, which can be a challenge for people who are not used to writing and research. One of the biggest difficulties with the class is figuring out how to write the papers to get an A, but if you focus on theory over experiment results, you'll get a high score.

Homework assignments, except for the first one, are fairly easy. Only the first one will be a major conceptual hurdle, but it's quite important for the rest of the class. Since the projects are so massive, I recommend doing the HWs ahead of time to leave more than 1 week for the project.

The most disappointing part of the class was the final exam. It felt poorly instrumented and had lots of confusing questions. Compared to how intellectually fulfilling the projects were, the exam felt like a major let down in terms of challenge. Most of the questions were on specific terms taught in the lectures, with some being more conceptual and interesting.

I hadn't taken intro to ML ahead of this, but I studied RL for my senior project during my Bachelors, including some practice with OpenAI Gym. I was pretty disappointed with the class being previously interested with RL, mostly because the material felt super theory heavy to me.

I made the mistake of only watching the lectures and sometimes doing the weekly readings. The lectures especially sometimes strayed too far into explaining proofs and writing down equation after equation (many of which were not super important to remember in the context of the class). The first third of the class I felt lost because of this. Watching David Silver's RL lectures was way more productive in my opinion, and those lectures are similarly based on the textbook for the class.

Homework assignments were really easy and helped teach more granular topics. Projects were a beast, mainly because of the condensed summer schedule. Definitely need to start a week or more early if you're not absolutely familiar with each topic. You have 5 page papers on top of writing code, and the projects are pretty open ended so sometimes it is difficult to decide if you're going in the right direction. I pulled last minute all nighters for all 3 projects, granted I did not take my own advice about working ahead. Despite all of that, I think it was a cool format that requires actual knowledge of the topic, you can't get away with just writing correct code. Two of the 3 topics weren't really that interesting, but the second project was awesome.

Overall this class definitely soured my feelings about RL. The topic seems like it's still very limited to the academic community compared to other ML subsets. Even though there's some cool problems, didn't really explore real-world applications. That was also emphasized by the class curriculum being pretty heavy on research papers (replicating them, learning course content from them, etc.).

## TLDR
I have mixed feelings about this class. On one hand, the material is very interesting. While I have a lot of experience in supervised and unsupervised ML, I had none in RL and learnt a great deal. The TAs were super knowledgeable and helpful. The homeworks are fairly easy to get 100% in. 

On the other hand, this is an incredibly demanding class. Most weeks I'd put 20-25 hours a minimum, some up to 40. The lectures are not great so I always had to supplement them with David Silver's lectures online, as well as attending office hours every week. There's also a ton of readings. The projects are incredibly time consuming. I would not recommend taking 2 classes if RL is one of them.

### Lectures
I didn't love the lectures. Some people really enjoyed the informal format of student-professor like lecture, but it didn't work for me. The examples were not clear and I found it much easier to watch David Silver's lectures on youtube. Definitely watch the lectures though, the final exam will be heavily based on what you learn in lectures. 

### Homework
There are 6 homework that account for 15% of the grade total. They actually get easier and easier. I'd say the first two homework are definitely the trickiest ones, and we had a lot of people post on Piazza saying they were dropping the class because they couldn't figure them out. If you end up in a similar situation, don't despair. They do get easier (towards the end, it would take at most an hour to figure them out), and the TAs always hold super helpful office hours

### Projects
There are 3 projects in this course, each accounting for 15% of your final grade. The first project asks you to read a paper and replicate some experiments in it. The second project is about developing some form of Q learning to solve a game (Lunar Lander) and the third project is another replication project.

The first project is the most straightforward. You should try your best to get 100% in that project since it only gets harder from there. The replications are fairly easy - most of the points will come from your report. Use the format the TA suggest, and write as much as you can (5 pages max).
